description: First Case of Coronavirus Confirmed in New York State
Governor Cuomo, declares state of emergency.
New York State announces it'll begin producing it's own brand of hand sanitizer.
Governor Cuomo, orders a coronavirus containment zone in New Rochelle, Westchester County, NY.
Restrictions on mass gatherings in effect, All gatherings of less than 500 people ordered to cut capacity by 50%. All gatherings of more than 500 people ordered to cancel.
All New York City schools ordered to close until April 20.
Governor Cuomo, signs executive order that mandates all but essential business to reduce their workforce density by 50% and have more employees work from home.
SUNY and CUNY schools suspend in person teaching and move to distance-learning model for the rest of the semester.
New York State on pause executive order commences, a state-wide stay-at-home order. All non-essential businesses ordered to close and non-essential gatherings canceled.
New York City surpasses 12,000 cases -- 35% of all COVID-19 cases in the U.S.
Governor Cuomo and health commissioner, Howard Zucker, issue state advisory that requires nursing homes to accept COVID-19 patients discharged from overwhelmed hospitals.
All non-essential construction sites ordered to shut down.
The New York City Health Department begins counting probable and not just confirmed COVID-19 deaths. The new policy drives up the nationwide death count by 17%.
Governor Cuomo, signs executive order requiring all state residents to wear face masks/coverings in public places where social distancing is not possible.
Stay-at-home order and school closures extended to May 15.
All schools and universities ordered to remain closed for the remainder of te academic year.
NYC subway closures from 1 a.m. to 5 a.m. during the coronavirus pandemic in order to disinfect trains and stations..
Statewide four-phase reopening plan is first announced.
The state Department of Health rescinds a March 25 order requiring nursing homes to accept elderly COVID-19 patients discharged from hospitals.
Statewide state of emergency extended to June 13.

Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, Southern Tier, North Country, and Central New York allowed to begin Phase 1 of the reopening plan and low risk business and recreational activities reopen including Landscaping, Gardening, Tennis & Drive-In-Movie Theaters
The MTA begins testing ultraviolet technology that is proved to kill COVID-19 on surfaces.
Gatherings of up to ten people allowed as long as social distancing is practiced.
New York City meets conditions for Phase 1, allowing the reopening of construction, manufacturing, agriculture, forestry, fishing, and select retail businesses that can offer curbside pickup.
Four-phase reopening plan is modified to allow non-essential gatherings of 25 people upon entry of Phase 3, and 50 people upon entry of Phase 4.

New York City meets conditions for Phase 2, allowing the reopening of outdoor dining at restaurants, hair salons and barber shops, offices, real estate firms, in-store retail, vehicle sales, retail rental, repair services, cleaning services, and commercial building management businesses.
New York began requiring travelers to self-quarantine for 14 days if traveling from an area with high infection rates.
Malls allowed to open at 25% capacity for regions in Phase 4, with all patrons required to wear masks
New restrictions on bars/restaurants only allowing alcohol to be served only to people ordering food.
Mayor de Blasio, announces New York City to begin imposing checkpoints to enforce quarantine order by Cuomo.
Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces schools can open in the fall if they publicly disclose plans to address remote learning, testing of virus, and tracing procedures.
Ban on ticketed music events at bars and restaurants.
Gyms and state-defined low-risk cultural institutions (like museums and aquariums) begin reopening
Malls in New York City and casinos statewide start to reopen
Governor Cuomo in conjunction with Governor Murphy of New Jersey, launch exposure notification apps COVID Alert NY and COVID Alert NJ which can notify users of potential exposure to COVID-19
Governor Cuomo introduced the micro-cluster strategy. The new plan places new restrictions in cluster areas that have spikes in COVID-19 cases.
Bars, gyms, and any other business with a liquor license must close by 10 p.m. (restaurants as well, except for curbside pickup). Household gatherings limited to ten people.
Previous restrictions on capacity through the micro-cluster strategy for places of worship is ruled unconstitutional.
Schools in the orange or red zone to allow in-person instruction as long as they test 25% of their students weekly.
Governor Cuomo directs hospital bed capacity to be upgraded by 25 percent and warns that indoor dining may face a total shutdown in the New York City area if hospitalization rates continued to climb.
Micro-cluster strategy modified to allow gyms and salons to operate in the orange zone" with increased testing and reduced capacity."
Following concerns over a new SARS-CoV-2 variant from the United Kingdom, Cuomo orders hospitals across the state to begin testing for the variant.
Governor Cuomo lifts nearly all Covid cluster zones, including those in Central NY

Investigation conducted by state attorney general Letitia James concludes that the Cuomo administration undercounted COVID-19-related deaths at nursing homes by as much as 50%. It became known as the New York COVID-19 nursing home scandal
91 businesses become exempt from the 10pm curfew on bars and restaurants due to a NYS Supreme Court ruling.
Governor Cuomo extended the curfew to 11pm for all bars and restaurants statewide.
Second lawsuit by 91 businesses resulted in them once again being exempt from the 11pm curfew.

Wedding reception venues allowed to open with a maximum of 150 people or 50% capacity, whichever condition is met first. All patrons must get tested (unless vaccinated) and events must be approved by the health department.
Capacity for gatherings increase with residential gatherings of up to 25 people outdoors or 10 people indoors, non-residential gatherings of up to 100 people indoors and up to 200 people outdoors.
Indoor entertainment facilities will be able to reopen at 25% capacity.
Governor Cuomo Announces Launch of Excelsior Pass, America's first vaccine passport
Outdoor amusement parks will be able to reopen at 33% capacity
Governor Cuomo Announces More Than 10.5 Million COVID-19 Vaccine Doses Have Been Administered in New York State.
Curfew for bars and restaurants was extended from 11pm to midnight.
Mandate requiring all alcohol purchases to be accompanied with food was removed.
Indoor Dining, Hair Salons, Barber Shops and Other Personal Care Services Will Expand to 75 Percent
Outdoor social gathering limit expands from 200 to 500 people.
Pools and beaches will be able to operate with six-foot social distancing and no percentage capacity limits by Memorial Day.
Governor Cuomo Announces State Will End Food and Beverage Service Curfew for outdoor dining areas.
